voice_principles.name: Benefit-led and outcome-focused
voice_principles.description: Webex talks about outcomes first: smoother work, better experiences, clearer insights. Features are always framed as enablers, not the hero.

examples.good: Route calls to the right agent faster so customers spend less time waiting.
examples.bad: This feature provides multiple routing options and queue settings.

voice_principles.name: Plain, human, and accessible
voice_principles.description: Use clear, everyday language that feels like a helpful colleague. Avoid heavy jargon; when acronyms are needed, define them in context.

examples.good: Automatic Call Distribution (ACD) sends callers to the best available agent.
examples.bad: ACD optimizes queue paths using advanced routing engines and proprietary logic.

voice_principles.name: Actionable and task-focused
voice_principles.description: Prefer imperative verbs and concrete steps. Tell people exactly what to do next, one action at a time.

examples.good: Open Control Hub, then go to Monitoring > Analytics > Calling.
examples.bad: Analytics can be accessed in various places within Control Hub.

voice_principles.name: Confident and reassuring
voice_principles.description: Sound calm, capable, and on top of things. Acknowledge issues, but focus on what will help users fix them or move forward.

examples.good: We could not reach your device. Check your network connection, then try again.
examples.bad: Something went wrong with an unknown error. Please contact support.

voice_principles.name: Insightful and data-aware
voice_principles.description: Where it helps, use concrete thresholds, metrics, or stats to define quality and guide decisions instead of vague labels.

examples.good: Calls are flagged as poor when packet loss is above 5 percent or latency is above 400 ms.
examples.bad: Calls are flagged as poor when overall network performance is not acceptable.

voice_principles.name: Hybrid-work and choice oriented
voice_principles.description: Recognize that people move between home, office, and mobile. Emphasize flexibility, continuity, and choice across devices and channels.

examples.good: Stay connected from your desk, your phone, or on the move without switching tools.
examples.bad: The service can be used in different environments when network conditions allow.

voice_principles.name: Role-aware but inclusive
voice_principles.description: Be explicit about who content is for. Speak directly to end users in second person, and describe admins or leaders in role-based third person.

examples.good: You can pause notifications on your phone. IT administrators can see overall quality trends in Control Hub.
examples.bad: Users and stakeholders can change settings and review analytics as needed.

tone_patterns.name: Marketing and overview
tone_patterns.use_for: Web pages, one-pagers, hero sections, feature overviews, launch emails.
tone_patterns.description: Upbeat, confident, and benefit-led. Highlights how Webex simplifies work, elevates experiences, and modernizes collaboration without sounding exaggerated.
tone_patterns.style: Short benefit headlines, present tense, light promotional phrases used sparingly, focus on outcomes for people and businesses.

example.after: Transform your calls with advanced features that keep you connected anywhere.

tone_patterns.name: In-product help and quick start
tone_patterns.use_for: Get started guides, panels, tooltips, walkthroughs, assistant prompts.
tone_patterns.description: Friendly, straightforward, and practical. Speaks directly to the user, showing how to complete tasks in a few clear steps.
tone_patterns.style: Second person, imperative steps, one action per sentence, simple headings like Messaging or Set up calling.

example.before: Meetings can be started and joined from the application as required.
example.after: Open the app. Select Meetings. Click Start a meeting to begin right away.

tone_patterns.name: Troubleshooting and errors
tone_patterns.use_for: Error messages, diagnostics panels, troubleshooting guides, support flows.
tone_patterns.description: Calm, direct, and slightly urgent. Focuses on what happened, what it affects, and what to try next. Reassures admins and users that issues can be resolved.
tone_patterns.style: Short plain statements of the problem, followed by clear next steps. Use checklists for settings and avoid blame or panic.

example.after: We could not connect this call. Check the number assignment, forwarding, and voicemail settings, then try again.

tone_patterns.name: Admin and IT guides
tone_patterns.use_for: Control Hub guides, deployment docs, analytics and quality documentation.
tone_patterns.description: Professional, authoritative, and data-backed. Acknowledges hybrid work challenges and shows how Webex and Control Hub provide visibility and control.
tone_patterns.style: Role-based third person for IT and business leaders, present tense, numeric stats and thresholds, outcomes such as reliability, security, and continuity.

example.before: Admins should consider many aspects of quality.
example.after: IT administrators need visibility into packet loss, jitter, and latency so they can maintain a high-quality experience for employees.

tone_patterns.name: End-user everyday app copy
tone_patterns.use_for: Desktop and mobile UI text, empty states, success messages, basic settings.
tone_patterns.description: Welcoming, empathetic, and low-pressure. Helps people stay in control of messages, meetings, and calls without feeling always on.
tone_patterns.style: Second person, mobile and life-context examples, mentions of balance and boundaries, simple tips and micro-CTAs.

example.before: Use Do Not Disturb to increase productivity at all times.
example.after: Turn on Do Not Disturb during quiet hours so you can focus or step away without missing important follow-ups later.

tone_patterns.name: Contact center leaders and buyers
tone_patterns.use_for: Contact center feature guides, decision-maker decks, CX-focused content.
tone_patterns.description: Polished, benefit-led, and operations-aware. Shows how features improve customer experience, agent productivity, and insight-driven decisions.
tone_patterns.style: Outcome-oriented descriptions of AI, routing, and analytics; defined acronyms; short CTAs to deeper setup or launch resources.

example.before: Webex Contact Center has AI features and ACD routing.
example.after: Webex Contact Center uses Automatic Call Distribution to send customers to the right agent and AI summaries to save agents time between interactions.

rules.description: Use second person for end-user copy; avoid generic users.
rules.do: Talk directly to the person using Webex.
rules.dont: Describe actions in distant, third-person language when you are giving user instructions.

example.good: You can mute notifications for this space when you need to focus.
example.bad: Users can mute notifications for spaces when they need to focus.

rules.description: Use role-based third person for admin and leader narratives.
rules.do: Name the role and describe what they need to see or do.
rules.dont: Address admins as a generic you in long-form strategy or buyer content.

example.good: IT administrators need a single place to deploy, monitor, and troubleshoot every device.
example.bad: You should try to keep an eye on all devices so your users stay happy.

rules.description: Lead with benefits in headings and intros, then mention features.
rules.do: Write short, sentence-case headlines that say what improves for the user or business.
rules.dont: Start with internal feature names or abstract labels only.

example.good: Cut wait times with smart call routing.

rules.description: Write steps and how-to content as imperative actions, one per line or sentence.
rules.do: Start steps with a verb and keep each one focused.
rules.dont: Pack multiple actions and conditions into one long sentence.

example.good: Open the Webex app. Select Meetings. Click Join next to the meeting you want.
example.bad: Meetings can be joined from the Webex app where the user is able to select the appropriate option.

rules.description: Keep headings short and in sentence case.
rules.do: Use sentence-case labels tied to tasks or features.
rules.dont: Use shouty all-caps or vague abstract headings.

rules.description: Avoid jargon. When an acronym is necessary, define it the first time in plain language.
rules.do: Pair the acronym with a short explanation of what it does or why it matters.
rules.dont: Assume everyone knows product and network acronyms.

example.good: Automatic Call Distribution (ACD) sends each caller to the best available agent.
example.bad: ACD controls all inbound call flows using complex rules.

rules.description: Use a consistent chevron pattern to describe navigation paths.
rules.do: Show the exact path with arrows between levels.
rules.dont: Tell users to hunt around without naming where to go.

example.good: In Control Hub, go to Monitoring > Analytics > Calling.
example.bad: In Control Hub, look through the menus until you find calling analytics.

rules.description: Always tie advanced features to the outcome they enable.
rules.do: Explain why someone would turn a feature on or when it helps.
rules.dont: List features without context or benefit.

example.good: Turn on background noise removal so your voice stays clear in busy spaces.
example.bad: Enable the background noise removal feature.

rules.description: Keep error and troubleshooting copy calm, clear, and action-oriented.
rules.do: State what went wrong and give one or two specific next steps.
rules.dont: Use dramatic language, blame the user, or leave them without direction.

example.good: We could not register this device. Check the activation code and network, then try again.
example.bad: Device registration failed. Please try again later.

rules.description: Where it helps decisions, use specific metrics instead of vague quality terms.
rules.do: Show thresholds or examples that define good, fair, or poor.
rules.dont: Rely only on labels like good quality or bad performance.

example.good: Investigate calls with jitter above 150 ms or packet loss above 5 percent.
example.bad: Investigate calls with unusually bad network quality.

rules.description: Present multiple settings or requirements as scannable lists, not dense paragraphs.
rules.do: Use short item lines or bullets for configuration checks.
rules.dont: Hide critical settings in a wall of text.

example.good: Check: main number assignment; number activation; call forwarding; voicemail; Do Not Disturb.
example.bad: Make sure you have a main number assigned, the number is activated, and call forwarding, voicemail, and Do Not Disturb are all configured correctly.

rules.description: Keep calls to action short, direct, and imperative.
rules.do: Use a simple verb plus object.
rules.dont: Embed CTAs inside long, formal sentences.

example.bad: For additional information about Control Hub, you may wish to consult the appropriate documentation.

rules.description: For mobile and notification features, emphasize control and balance, not 24 by 7 responsiveness.
rules.do: Show how to set boundaries, quiet hours, or reminders that reduce stress.
rules.dont: Encourage always-on behavior or constant monitoring.

example.good: Set quiet hours so Webex only alerts you during your workday.
example.bad: Use notifications to stay on top of new messages at all times.

rules.description: Use playful or strong reassurance phrases sparingly and only in marketing-style contexts.
rules.do: Reserve lines like no problem or just leveled up for campaign headlines or hero copy.
rules.dont: Use overpromising phrases in error messages, troubleshooting, or sensitive admin flows.

example.good: Your calling experience just leveled up with new AI-powered features.
example.bad: No problem, this error will never happen again.
